{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3396089,"name":"","username":"shaoshuaizyk","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c5a1d2/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-06T18:54:48.399Z","cooked":"

Hi community, I am testing the new Kraken X60 motor without loading by different control modes in Phoenix 6. I tried closed-loop velocity control which works smoothly. The position closed-loop control works OK but due to lack of limitation of the speed, it spins very fast and could jump out of the table. However, something strange takes place when I test the Magic Motion by the following code:

#!/usr/bin/env python3

from phoenix6 import hardware, unmanaged, controls, configs, StatusCode
import time

def main():
	#Initialization
	motor = hardware.TalonFX(0, "can0")

	motion_magic = controls.MotionMagicVoltage(0).with_slot(0)
	brake = controls.NeutralOut()

	# Setup configurations
	cfg = configs.TalonFXConfiguration()

	# Configure Motion Magic
	mm = cfg.motion_magic
	mm.motion_magic_cruise_velocity = 1 # 1 rotations per second cruise
	mm.motion_magic_acceleration = 1 # Take approximately 1 seconds to reach max vel
	# Take apprximately 1 seconds to reach max accel
	mm.motion_magic_jerk = 1

	slot0 = cfg.slot0
	slot0.k_s = 0.0 # It used to be 0.25 but I changed it to 0.0. Add 0.25 V output to overcome static friction
	slot0.k_v = 0.12 # A velocity target of 1 rps results in 0.12 V output
	slot0.k_a = 0.01 # An acceleration of 1 rps/s requires 0.01 V output
	slot0.k_p = 1 # It used to be 60 but I changed it to 1 but still shaking. 
	slot0.k_i = 0 # No output for integrated error
	slot0.k_d = 0.5 # A velocity error of 1 rps results in 0.5 V output

	# Sleep 7 seconds to wait for the initialization
	time.sleep(7)

	# Retry config apply up to 5 times, report if failure
	status: StatusCode = StatusCode.STATUS_CODE_NOT_INITIALIZED
	for _ in range(0, 5):
		status = motor.configurator.apply(cfg)
		if status.is_ok():
			print(f"Apply the configs successfully!")
			break
	else:
		print(f"Could not apply configs, error code: {status.name}")

	# Make sure we start at 0
	motor.set_position(0)
	# Wait for the set up working
	time.sleep(1)
	pos = motor.get_position()
	vel = motor.get_velocity()
	print(f"Motor: \nPosition is {str(pos)} with {pos.timestamp.get_latency()} seconds of latency. \nVelocity is {str(vel)} with {vel.timestamp.get_latency()} seconds of latency.")

	while True:
		unmanaged.feed_enable(60000)
		# motion.set_control(brake)

		desired_rotations = float(input("Please input the desired rotations: "))
		print(f"Rotate {desired_rotations}.")

		if abs(desired_rotations) < 1:
			print(f"Input not larger than one rotation, brake the motor!")
			motor.set_control(brake)
		else:
			motor.set_control(motion_magic.with_position(desired_rotations))

		# # Wait for finishing
		# time.sleep(2)

		pos = motor.get_position()
		vel = motor.get_velocity()

		print(f"Motor: \nPosition is {str(pos)} with {pos.timestamp.get_latency()} seconds of latency. \nVelocity is {str(vel)} with {vel.timestamp.get_latency()} seconds of latency.")
		# motor.set_position(0)


if __name__ == "__main__":
	main()

If I input 2 rotations, it starts to spin slowly but with vibration. Once it finishes the spin, it starts vibrating/shaking severely and causes loud noises. I tried two different motors. One gave the behavior described above, the other didn’t vibrate with loud noise but the spinning was still not smoothy. According to my knowledge of control theory, it seems unstable under this situation but I have already set a very strict velocity, acceleration and jerk limitation. I am not sure if the shaking is due to the hardware or it could be eliminated by tuning the parameters. Does anyone have the similar issue and do you have any suggestions about my test? Thanks!

slot0.k_d = 0.5

That kD seems high, which could cause stuttering since the controller is severely overcorrecting for velocity error. Try reducing it to a value <= 0.1 V/rps.

I’m guessing you got the original PID gains from our Python Motion Magic example. However, that example also sets the sensor_to_mechanism_ratio to 12.8, which specifies the gear ratio between the Talon FX and the mechanism. PID gains need to scale linearly with sensor_to_mechanism_ratio, so the gains in the example will be up to a factor of 12.8 too large for your code (where the ratio is 1).
